11.96.text:
It's great that you're all here
because I know with the Pope in town,

17.04.text:
I myself got stuck this morning,
it wasn't easy to come here, so

21.76.text:
I'm actually impressed that the room is so
full.

25.39.text:
There we go, my presentation works and
I can get started.

28.04.text:
So when the folks from Columbia
asked me to come here and

32.78.text:
speak this morning,
give the keynote speech,

34.97.text:
they just said just tell your story and
that's the most interesting thing.

39.04.text:
Don't try to come up with any
philosophical statements,

43.32.text:
And I was like okay,
that's easy I can do that and many of you

47.71.text:
actually probably have similar backgrounds
than me, that's what I'm assuming.

51.19.text: I obviously don't know you but

53.35.text:
maybe some of what I did will also be
something that's interesting for you or

57.39.text:
some areas might inspire you or also
not but I'll just put it out there so.

63.69.text:
My life started in a quiet,
let's say linear, way.

68.20.text:
I went to school, I went to university and
pretty much after that

73.80.text:
I went into a typical corporate consulting
background, and started with that.

80.92.text:
In some ways I didn't really
think about what I wanted to do.

84.97.text:
That was kind of the thing that everyone
was doing and I just went along that path.

89.85.text: And I started with BCG in Munich.

93.67.text:
But relatively soon I was like okay,
I've done this and now in Germany.

96.80.text:
That's where I'm from in
case anyone was wondering.

99.84.text:
And then I said hm,
what can be my next step.

104.01.text:
Back then I hadn't heard
about social business yet.

106.52.text:
Hadn't heard about microfinance,
none of that.

108.73.text:
But I said, okay,
why don't I go to New York?

111.58.text:
This amazing fabled city, this capital of
capitalism that all of you guys live in.

117.56.text: I was like, why don't I try that out?

119.43.text:
So I transferred with NBCG,
went to New York,

122.94.text:
started consulting some
consumer goods companies here.

127.54.text:
But relatively soon I again had that
feeling similar to what I had in Germany,

134.39.text:
And relatively quickly I actually started
asking myself why am I doing all this?

140.48.text:
Not what am I just gonna do next,
but why am I actually doing this?

144.06.text:
And I think that was the first time in my
life that I actually, after really running

148.91.text:
that very typical career path, started
thinking, what do I wanna do with my life?

154.82.text:
Am I gonna do this for the rest of
my life or can I, in some ways,

159.45.text:
see how my skills could possibly
be used for something slightly

164.17.text:
broader than just helping
corporates improve their profits?

168.90.text:
And I think that's when about age 27 or so
I fell into this quarter life crisis or

174.15.text:
whatever you want to call it, not
midlife crisis, I wasn't old enough yet.

179.82.text:
And I was just asking myself,
my God what am I gonna do?

183.80.text:
And I guess I also noticed
relatively clearly that I was

187.11.text:
part of this specific generation,
this Generation Y.

191.30.text:
That do not only believe
in their own career, but

194.84.text:
that also wanna do something
more broader for society.

197.24.text:
And I guess this is
probably nothing new for

201.16.text: you guys because you're younger than me.

203.30.text:
So you probably all belong to the
millennial generation that anyway totally

206.81.text: has that completely ingrained in your DNA.

209.95.text:
But when I tell these stories let's
say in front of corporate guys or

213.82.text:
investors they're like why do you want
to do something for society at large?

221.04.text: You'll understand me better I hope.

224.92.text:
Yeah so in the process I kind of
started doing some research because

228.62.text:
I have been very lucky I grew
up in a nice little neighborhood

236.53.text:
I had wonderful parents, my mother being
Canadian, my father being German so

240.35.text:
I was in that sense totally
privileged in terms of my passports,

244.38.text:
in terms of the education
I was allowed to do,

246.28.text:
in terms of the healthcare that I just
basically had for free at my doorstep.

250.90.text:
And I started doing some
research about the world, and

254.39.text:
realized that what I had was
certainly not at all normal.

259.56.text:
And so what I found out there, which also
again, you guys as millennials nowadays,

266.43.text:
half of the world's wealth is
with 1% of the population.

270.90.text:
And the other half of that
wealth is with the other 99%.

275.79.text: So, I was like, that's crazy,

278.02.text:
what kind of a system have we built
up that that is actually true?

283.72.text:
And of course you guys all living in
New York, this is a city of extremes.

287.61.text:
You have many of those
1% living right here.

290.34.text:
You probably all know
many of those 1% and, and

294.03.text:
so that other side is important to keep
in mind as well because sometimes we're

298.66.text:
sipping our latte and
completely forget about those other 50%.

302.19.text: So that's what I learned back then, and

304.50.text:
that was a pretty shocking revelation for
me.

308.06.text:
I was like oh my God,
how are we gonna change this inequality?

312.72.text: Still sitting here in New York.

315.01.text:
And then I heard about these
millennium development goals.

318.79.text: Have you guys heard about them?

320.09.text:
Who has heard about
the millennium development goals?

325.68.text:
Not surprising here at
Columbia Business School.

327.72.text:
So, and I heard about these eight goals,
and I was like, whoa okay,

331.84.text:
so the world has come together
behind these eight goals, and

336.54.text:
the major kinda top line
is to half poverty by 2015.

339.30.text:
And I heard about that and
I was like okay, thank God.

342.64.text:
There is at least some kind
of a plan in place it seems.

346.43.text:
And actually to be honest,
I have to say now, in 2015,

349.38.text:
this is the year when
they're supposed to end.

352.78.text:
And the world has made significant and
good progress.

355.33.text:
There's still some areas where
the eight goals have not been reached.

358.27.text:
But it has, it definitely has
been going in a good direction.

361.83.text:
So I had realized I had won the lottery,
and, of life,

365.96.text: clearly, with what I was just explaining.

368.96.text:
And so I thought maybe there's
something that I can do.

373.50.text:
I was just talking about those goals
that had come together in 2000,

378.41.text:
and then that were supposed
to be ending this year.

382.22.text:
And there was a little bit of a dip
in attention for those goals.

394.39.text: Corporates and banks were going bust.

397.45.text: The whole world economy was slumping.

399.32.text:
And suddenly, nobody really cared about
those millennium development goals anymore

403.51.text:
and a lot of attention was
really lost back then.

406.90.text:
And back then,
also me business school background,

409.82.text:
working in corporate consulting,
I had thought that actually

413.25.text:
business would be a great contributor
to those millennium development goals.

417.61.text:
But suddenly this whole system
that we had though was one that

421.32.text:
could potentially also help was
all crumbling and falling apart.

425.85.text:
So I'm look ew okay, capitalism is
obviously not gonna solve it cuz

429.84.text:
they've actually created this system and
they're not contributing because right now

433.18.text:
there's a financial crisis and they

And so they say who's now going to help
achieve those millennium development goals

440.93.text:
Then I was like, okay,
can governments do anything?

444.53.text:
Well here in the US that's certainly not
a solution that you probably believe in,

452.53.text:
and after the financial crisis
the sovereign debt crisis hit, and

456.52.text:
particularly in Europe, where I'm from,
we're still battling with some of that.

460.00.text:
I mean still until now we've been
working on the bailout of Greece and

465.12.text:
So that institution suddenly
didn't really work anymore.

468.39.text:
And I was like, so, who's gonna
actually help achieve those goals and

472.26.text:
who's actually gonna help stop that
inequality that we see all around us?

476.33.text:
So I was like, okay,
not capitalism, not governments.

479.59.text:
NGO sector, maybe, but also there I didn't
really see how that was gonna work.

484.37.text:
So, I figured out,
it probably has to be individuals.

488.60.text:
It has to be every individual one of us
that just takes their own initiative and

495.24.text:
And with all of this backdrop and things
that I had in mind at that stage in this

500.18.text:
kind of transition period
that I That I was.

503.28.text:
I just said, okay,
you know what, I'll go London.

506.59.text:
I'll move there,
I'll spend a luxury year and

509.77.text:
study, do another Masters
about International Relations.

513.96.text:
And with all that backdrop at LSE I
heard this guy speak, Muhammad Yunus.

524.75.text: I don't need to ask anymore questions.

526.72.text:
[LAUGH] So, I heard them speak,
and I was just blown away.

533.36.text:
He was standing up there and
he was telling story.

536.90.text:
And I just thought, wow,
that's one individual and

540.73.text:
he's actually managed
to do all this things.

544.05.text:
Maybe with my small skill set that
I have I can do something too.

548.96.text:
And most people probably
know him from Microcredit.

552.53.text:
That's what he's known for, that's
what he won the Peace Noble Prize for.

557.37.text:
That's for what he has I don't know
47 honorary doctorates at different

561.83.text:
universities around the world, but
I don't know what other things he's won.

566.36.text:
But he started talking, also,
about this new concept of social business.

572.16.text:
And that's something that I
hadn't really heard about before.

574.36.text:
I knew about micro-finance, and
I thought that was a cool thing.

577.70.text:
But I didn't really know about this
conceptualization of social business.

581.68.text:
And what I was very impressed of was
that this institution of business

587.29.text:
that I believed in,
that I had a background in, and

590.92.text:
that I have learned, was completely only
focused on shareholder value maximization,

596.33.text:
suddenly could also be used for
not shareholder value maximization,

603.57.text:
Of humanity, of environments, of the world
as a whole, and that really impressed me.

610.25.text: And the thing was that this guy, Yunus,

613.51.text:
he was not just a person that had
come up beautiful theories, and

618.06.text:
was a nice professor coming up with
them and writing them on paper.

622.85.text:
But he had been a practitioner,
and he had gotten this done.

627.08.text:
And he had implemented social business
at large scale in Bangladesh.

633.37.text:
And Bangladesh is certainly not an easy
country to start something like this in,

638.86.text: and he had managed to do this.

640.90.text: And here you go with a few examples of

644.30.text:
some of those businesses that were created
over the last 30 years in Bangladesh.

648.67.text: I'll just give you a few examples.

649.96.text:
For example, next to the lack of
access to finance that people have in

654.14.text:
rural Bangladesh, they also don't
really have access to healthcare.

658.97.text:
So, you said okay, let's try and
build some clinics but

662.45.text:
build some clinics not in a way that you,
get a donation, build a clinic, and

669.44.text:
But a clinic that charges very small
amounts so everyone can still pay for

674.87.text:
it but that, again,
functions financially self-sustainable,

678.22.text:
recoups its costs and, again,
therefore, grow on its own steam.

682.49.text:
Same thing was they don't have access
to electricity in rural Bangladesh.

686.97.text:
It's not like here where you just plug in
your cell phone and then it's loading.

693.06.text: You all know this as well.

695.78.text: So how do you find a solution?

700.40.text:
they said in Bangladesh, well,
why don't we sell the people solar panels?

706.58.text:
In the mid 90s solar panels were quite
a radical idea because certainly,

712.76.text:
neither in the US nor in Europe,
that was like a big thing.

716.71.text: And solar power even now a days is not

719.79.text:
really a strong proportion
of our energy mix.

722.94.text: And they just started selling those.

724.94.text:
And Grameen Shakti now is actually
one of the largest solar home system

730.51.text: Not just in Bangladesh, but in the world.

732.84.text:
They've sold over one and a half million
solar home systems to individual homes,

737.25.text: at a low price, so people can afford it.

739.59.text:
They don't have to pay for
kerosene anymore and again,

742.58.text: the whole thing functions as a business.

745.06.text:
That's just another example,
maybe I'll throw a third one in there too.

748.28.text:
Also in the mid 90's,
also quite radical, and

752.21.text:
people didn't really have phones, cell
phones especially not in rural Bangladesh.

756.75.text:
Even in the mid 90's I didn't have
a phone in good old Germany, so

762.20.text:
he just started saying why don't we
start selling people cellphones so

766.97.text:
they can actually
communicate with each other?

768.81.text:
So they can actually find out when they
want to sell lets say their potatoes

773.93.text: What the price in the next village is.

776.02.text:
They can just call their
friend in another village.

777.76.text:
And suddenly they have this
market transparency and

780.22.text:
they suddenly have the power
of information in their hands.

784.84.text: They did it, okay another success story.

788.34.text:
Grameen Phone is now the largest
company in Bangladesh.

792.84.text:
It's the largest tax-payer,
it has around 50% market share.

799.55.text:
But again, it was not created to to make
money for Yunus or Grameen or anyone.

805.15.text:
It was created to solve that problem so
people have access to information,

808.97.text:
can communicate with each other,
and are connected to the world.

812.53.text: And so these are just a few examples.

816.71.text:
I think the word disruption,
or game-changing,

822.37.text: You probably are very aware of that.

824.67.text:
But for me, those are examples
that are real game changers,

828.09.text:
that change the way life was for
people in Bangladesh.

833.04.text:
And these are the types of businesses that
we're trying to support around the world

839.58.text:
So let me just clarify what we
mean with social business and

843.08.text:
again for you guys its pretty clear,
but just to put it in a nutshell.

847.52.text:
It really has created out of the intention
of a solving specific social problem,

853.67.text:
but it does run fully
financial self sustainable.

856.39.text:
It can completely run on it's own steam
It can repay the initial capital and

861.22.text:
it reinvests the money
into the specific mission.

864.85.text:
So, in some ways, and I know that
this is completely over the top.

868.81.text:
But I'm allowed to say this because I come
from that side of the business world.

873.83.text:
In some ways, typical business has
been concentrated on one thing.

878.71.text:
They've been kind of trained, just like
that dog has been trained to bite,

883.54.text:
and normal business has
been trained to bite or

888.40.text:
get money out of the system and
give money to their shareholders.

893.78.text:
But then why can you not take that exact
same machine, that efficiency machine,

899.69.text:
that machine that is driving us in
the world, that machine called business.

904.04.text:
But changed the DNA slightly,
so let's say,

907.48.text:
genetically modify that thing called
business and suddenly say, you know what?

913.63.text:
Do the same thing, but
your goal is suddenly a different one.

918.70.text:
It's actually solving
a problem in your community.

921.87.text: And that's where you see that same dog.

923.77.text:
He's also programmed it a different way
and he's a, I don't even know what you

927.36.text:
call that in English,
a blinds dog or something like that.

930.63.text:
He's helping a blind guy to walk
around and it's the same dog,

933.13.text: but he's serving a different purpose.

936.00.text: So that's what I found fascinating.

938.42.text:
And so
obviously as you know I got involved.

941.04.text: After the speech I walked up to Yunus,

942.90.text:
I was like my My name is here's my
business card, can we work together?

948.10.text: And he said, sure, who are you?

951.76.text:
And we started emailing
relatively quickly,

955.57.text: I then started going to Bangladesh.

958.59.text:
Because I just thought, okay, I have
to go to where this guy is from, and

962.42.text: see what he's actually done in reality.

964.63.text: I said bye bye to BCG.

966.39.text:
Flew to Bangladesh and then said, is there
a way that I can use my current skills?

973.84.text:
And I started calling up
my former clients at PCG,

977.31.text:
started partnering up
with another partner.

980.47.text:
And we started creating
companies together.

985.09.text:
So companies that were founded in
partnership between Grameen and

989.10.text:
Unis and Bangladesh, but also some of
the corporates that I used to work for.

993.73.text:
And so one of them, for example,
was the joint venture with BASF.

998.03.text:
BASF, as you might know, is Is the largest
chemical company in the world.

1001.86.text: So first of all, you think like, ugh.

1004.00.text: Maybe a scary company to work with.

1006.40.text:
But they said, hey, we want to use also

1011.59.text:
So what we did is,
we created a company that produces and

1015.71.text:
sells mosquito nets that are treated
with a certain insecticide.

1020.40.text:
And to be able to combat malaria, dengue
fever and other insect-borne diseases.

1024.58.text:
And that company was created and
it's still running.

1028.26.text:
It produces about 3,000 nets a day and

1031.93.text:
So that's just one example,
but there were many others.

1034.60.text:
We created another one with Veolia
which is a French utility company

1038.97.text:
to make sure that people had safe
drinking water in Bangladesh.

1043.07.text:
the water is contaminated with arsenic,
the groundwater.

1047.08.text:
And the surface water is contaminated just
with germs so people get diarrhea, etc.

1051.64.text:
Grameen Veolia makes clean water so
people have access to it, and sells it.

1056.66.text:
Again, it's not a charity,
it's a business.

1059.48.text:
So just a few of those
examples that we then created.

1063.65.text:
So all of that was then
focused on Bangladesh.

1066.30.text: So then I said, the world is big and

1069.37.text:
he's obviously is traveling
around the world everyday.

1073.61.text:
Obviously he knew that very well, and
I said why don't we try and see if

1077.55.text:
we can replicate that success that you've

1082.17.text:
Because there's so much need in the world,
why don't we try and do that?

1087.88.text: And he said sure, why not?

1089.53.text:
Let's try.
As crazy as he was,

1091.08.text: the entrepreneur that he was, he agreed.

1092.62.text:
So we co-founded Unis Social Business
Global Initiatives in 2011 and

1098.87.text: now we have expanded, whoops no.

1103.18.text: There's one more thing I wanted to say.

1106.63.text: So, he was a game changer.

1108.69.text:
How can we find game
changers around the world?

1111.20.text:
That's what we set out
to do at that stage.

1114.06.text:
I don't know know if we're 100% there yet,

1116.93.text: And you'll see a few examples.

1119.26.text:
So, we expanded into seven regions now,

1123.87.text:
But seven major regions where
we have teams on the ground.

1128.50.text:
And I think we've had some

1138.06.text:
And we have invested nowadays
into 30 social businesses,

1142.89.text:
in different areas
ranging from agriculture,

1146.68.text:
to education,
to vocational training, you name it.

1151.05.text:
Renewable energy, many,
many different areas.

1154.36.text:
Those social businesses in turn, just

1157.82.text:
because those are the ones where we can

1161.30.text:
They've already served about 400,000

1166.11.text:
They created around 10,000
jobs at this stage.

1171.18.text:
So there's some significant impact and

1175.25.text:
because those 30 businesses started

1180.01.text:
And as they're growing, each year

1183.22.text:
And we will additionally invest

1186.72.text:
And so,
the impact will be growing every year.

1190.80.text: So, how do we find those entrepreneurs?

1193.99.text:
There are really two ways how we
do that in all those countries.

1197.28.text:
In all those countries we have people
on the grounds that do nothing else

1202.27.text:
than look for local entrepreneurs,
and then pick them.

1207.13.text: Pick the ones that they find are the best.

1209.31.text: And they provide them with all of it,

1211.06.text:
let's say non financial support what we

1215.14.text:
Everything from helping them to
find clients to helping them to

1219.52.text:
I don't know be better in marketing or

1224.08.text:
Connecting them to experts, connecting
them to mentors and then when we feel that

1228.61.text:
they are investment ready then we also
provide the necessary financing, so

1234.73.text: So that's how we generally do that.

1238.41.text:
Then, I'd like to share a few
examples with you, just so

1242.40.text:
you see a few stories and
you can imagine again what we mean

1246.94.text:
when we talk about social business,
and what is also doable right now.

1251.20.text:
We do focus, as I said,
on early stage social businesses.

1254.07.text:
So we're not looking for somebody that
has been in operation for 10, 15 years.

1258.75.text:
But we're trying to actually find those
guys that are really starting off, that

1262.13.text:
have maybe created some early revenue,
but that we still need help to grow.

1267.64.text:
Because we see that's where
the largest gap in the market is.

1271.15.text:
There are banks that can finance
organizations that are much more advanced.

1276.99.text:
And also other impact investors can
come in with higher investments.

1282.18.text:
So we've actually picked that
specific so-called missing middle.

1286.73.text:
And this is, for example,
one of my heroes, Robert.

1290.57.text: He's a guy from Northern Uganda, and

1294.20.text:
Northern Uganda obviously was hit by

1299.33.text:
The Lord's Resistance Army
was quite terrible and

1304.87.text:
And so the region is pretty much

And Robert was from there and he said,
I wanna do something for my area.

1315.70.text:
I wanna make sure that we
have economic growth here.

And so he just started off with

He started producing honey for himself,

1327.44.text:
Then he got a few unemployed

why don't you produce honey with me and

And now, just after a few years he

1344.07.text:
around 5,000 formerly unemployed youth in

1350.70.text: And he's created this honey brand called,

1354.38.text:
that he's now been selling both in
the Kampala area, in the capitol city,
